issue.title: Enables updating the configured min-level overrides at runtime
issue.body:
In response to https://github.com/serilog/serilog-settings-configuration/issues/284#issuecomment-1289664499, this PR shows my attempt to add the ability to replace the set of minimum log level overrides at runtime. The goal is to make it possible to refresh when appsettings.json changes on disk.

My approach attempts to avoid compromising performance or multicore contention at:
https://github.com/serilog/serilog/blob/4d13be50c03e14b6072043799dc7e5dbe4139a19/src/Serilog/Core/LevelOverrideMap.cs#L35-L41
by atomically updating the `LevelOverrideMap` reference with a new snapshot, instead of switching to a concurrent collection.

comment.body:
Thanks for taking a look! Unfortunately, the `IDisposable` implementation on `Logger` is only exposed on the root logging pipeline; child loggers like those produced by `ForContext` are exposed only as the non-disposable `ILogger`, and the API doesn't require or allow disposing these, so the changes would leak all child loggers via their event subscriptions.

The event handling subscribe/unsubscribe/synchronization costs are also a significant factor since in Serilog's design, contextual loggers are cheap/throwaway - it's common to see them created at pretty high frequency.

Digging through this again is reminding me why my conclusions last time were that it's a feature that's somewhat at odds with the way Serilog is designed. Still happy digging in, here, but thinking chances of finding a successful approach might be modest :-)

Just thinking back to your original ticket for a second - have you investigated the reconfigurable "reloadable logger" approach that we currently bundle up with Serilog.Extensions.Hosting?:

https://github.com/serilog/serilog-extensions-hosting/blob/dev/src/Serilog.Extensions.Hosting/Extensions/Hosting/ReloadableLogger.cs

It's fully reconfigurable; it's designed to be eventually "frozen" into a permanent, non-reconfigurable form, but you may have some luck incorporating it/tweaking it to reduce the costs of keeping it in a permanently mutable state 🤔 ... let me know if this might be a lower-effort way to get the behavior you're after.

issue.title: Plan of attack/call-to-action
issue.body:
I've dug into the official OpenTelemetry libraries for .NET - there's a lot of machinery there, and it seems questionable to want to run it all side-by-side with Serilog (better to use one or the other).

From that point of view, given the ultimate simplicity of the OTel logs protocol, I think the sink will be more useful by taking a lightweight approach and implementing the protocol directly with HTTP or gRPC and protocol buffers.

Here's my current plan - anyone interested in lending a hand, please let me know :-)

 - [ ] generate gRPC client types based on the protocol spec; see e.g. `OpenTelemetry.Exporter.OpenTelemetryProtocol.csproj` in the `opentelemetry-dotnet` repo
 - [ ] implement a mapping from batched `LogEvent`s to `ExportLogsServiceRequest`s
 - [ ] figure out what the sink's `Options` type will look like - e.g. accept the collector's HTTP base URL, etc.
 - [ ] implement _Serilog.Sinks.PeriodicBatching_'s `IBatchedLogEventSink` to construct requests, blast them through an `HttpClient`
 - [ ] wire everything up through logger sink configuration extensions
 - [ ] make some calls on how ambient trace and span ids will be determined by the sink (i.e. either through enriched log events, or by collecting them directly)

... or something close to that!

issue.title: Remove Sinks at runtime via XML
issue.body:
**Does this issue relate to a new *feature* or an existing *bug*?**
- [ ] Bug
- [x] New Feature
- [x] Question


Is it possible to remove a Sink via XML/configuration? 

It is possible to add a Sink via XML:

```XML
    <add key="serilog:using:RollingFile" value="Serilog.Sinks.RollingFile" />
    <add key="serilog:write-to:RollingFile.pathFormat" value="D:\log-{Date}.txt" />
```

But now I have the following situation: In a helper class I have a method (so in code) that creates a "default Serilog LoggerConfiguration". Multiple apps/libs can use this so the configuration is managed in a central place. 
But now I want to remove a sink for a specific app, at runtime.

Is it possible / It would be nice to remove a sink via XML, like:
```XML
    <add key="serilog:remove:using:RollingFile" value="Serilog.Sinks.RollingFile" />
```

This way I can "override" my default LoggerConfiguration that I have defined in code.

comment.body: Serilog 2.12's `CreateBootstrapLogger()` now provides this; please check out https://nblumhardt.com/2020/10/bootstrap-logger/ for one example of usage. If you need help figuring out how to integrate it into your app, the `serilog` tag on Stack Overflow is the most active channel. Thanks!

issue.title: Update OpenSSL to exclude the possibility of any impact from CVE-2022-3602 and CVE-2022-3786
issue.body:
[CVE-2022-3602 and CVE-2022-3786](https://www.openssl.org/news/secadv/20221101.txt) affect the OpenSSL library, which appears in various contexts platform library or embedded dependency. These issues are currently understood to be denial-of-service vectors causing application crashes on mainstream platforms.

We're currently investigating potential impacts on Seq. At this point we expect impact to be low, however we expect to publish patched releases for all target platforms regardless.

issue.title: Add queue monitoring
issue.body:
This PR implements issue #61 .

I changed my mind on the way to monitor the queue...

Instead of configuring just a threshold that would trigger one callback when going above and another one when going below as proposed in the issue, i figured it is more interesting to monitor it "real time" with a timer and a callback that takes the number of events in the queue.

The hard part was to have a not flaky unit test (combination of the new monitoring timer with the existing timer was quite hard to synchronize in tests). After a lot of effort to try to make it work, i decided to create a way to mock the timers and have a better control over the timing.

The impact of this refactoring seems reasonable to me as there is no change publicly, just a new internal constructor only visible in tests (so the PortableTimer is still not visible by users of the lib).

Let me know if you agree with the approach !

issue.title: No exceptions emitted when generated by faulty audit log configuration
issue.body:
Combining this with an audit log Serilog configuration, exceptions are swallowed and never emitted back to the caller as would be expected.

Steps to reproduce:

1. Set up an audit logging configuration for Serilog which is purposefully mal-configured (for example, using the MS SQL Server sink to log events to a non-existent database table).
2. Implement logging using Microsoft.Extensions.Logging.Abstractions and an ILogger<T> using this library.
3. Emit a log event (`logger.LogInformation("test");`)

Expected behaviour: Exception to be thrown at the call to `LogInformation()`.

Actual behaviour:

- No exception is thrown
- The underlying exception is visible in Serilog's SelfLog

It looks like the culprit of this behaviour is here:

https://github.com/serilog/serilog-extensions-logging/blob/7141ae23125cbdb6b67df6f9aab1c42f1fa58366/src/Serilog.Extensions.Logging/Extensions/Logging/SerilogLogger.cs#L67-L74

Apologies for posting this up as an issue with no accompanying pull request but that's somewhat down to time constraints right now and largely because I'm not sure what the implications of changing this are likely to be. The obvious fix for this specific problem as I see it would just be to get rid of the try/catch block entirely and assume that if an exception is encountered, it's something we care about. However I am aware that my scenario is probably quite specific (it seems like audit logging is far less common than regular logging where errors _should_ be ignored) and my proposed 'fix' might well create new problems for people in other scenarios. And/or not account for other possible causes of exceptions which don't relate to the underlying Serilog logger having emitted them.

Let me know if I can add anything more to clarify and/or if I'm barking up the wrong tree here with this.

comment.body:
Thanks for the follow-up, Mark.

On the paths where you need auditing, perhaps using Serilog's `ILogger`/`Log` class directly is the way to go? Cheers!

issue.title: No exceptions emitted when generated by faulty audit log configuration
issue.body:
Combining this with an audit log Serilog configuration, exceptions are swallowed and never emitted back to the caller as would be expected.

Steps to reproduce:

1. Set up an audit logging configuration for Serilog which is purposefully mal-configured (for example, using the MS SQL Server sink to log events to a non-existent database table).
2. Implement logging using Microsoft.Extensions.Logging.Abstractions and an ILogger<T> using this library.
3. Emit a log event (`logger.LogInformation("test");`)

Expected behaviour: Exception to be thrown at the call to `LogInformation()`.

Actual behaviour:

- No exception is thrown
- The underlying exception is visible in Serilog's SelfLog

It looks like the culprit of this behaviour is here:

https://github.com/serilog/serilog-extensions-logging/blob/7141ae23125cbdb6b67df6f9aab1c42f1fa58366/src/Serilog.Extensions.Logging/Extensions/Logging/SerilogLogger.cs#L67-L74

Apologies for posting this up as an issue with no accompanying pull request but that's somewhat down to time constraints right now and largely because I'm not sure what the implications of changing this are likely to be. The obvious fix for this specific problem as I see it would just be to get rid of the try/catch block entirely and assume that if an exception is encountered, it's something we care about. However I am aware that my scenario is probably quite specific (it seems like audit logging is far less common than regular logging where errors _should_ be ignored) and my proposed 'fix' might well create new problems for people in other scenarios. And/or not account for other possible causes of exceptions which don't relate to the underlying Serilog logger having emitted them.

Let me know if I can add anything more to clarify and/or if I'm barking up the wrong tree here with this.

comment.body:
Thanks for the report, Mark!

Here's the original bug that led to the introduction of the try/catch block:

https://github.com/serilog/serilog-extensions-logging/issues/164

I'm not sure what the right approach is, needs some more consideration 🤔

issue.title: Serilog.Sinks.OpenTelemetry
issue.body:
**Description**
The main thing I want to implement is, I have to post logs into LocalStack awsclouwatch.
As we have post logs into the LocalStack awscloudwatch service using serilog the same need to implement using opentelemetry.

Since I can't find much on above statement, I thought to use serilog extension to post logs into the OpenTelemtry and use the existing flow of using serilog to see those OpenTelemetry logs in LocalStack awscloudewatch. 

For that I Used **Serilog.OpenTelemetry" Version="2.1.0"** nuget package but I am facing issues with
-  an extention method OpenTelemetry. 
-  Sdk.CreateLoggerProviderBuilder()
- not getting a reference of a class OpenTelemetrySerilogSink 
Since, above issues are with this nuget, just would like to ask,

Do Serilog provide any extension functionality compatible with OpenTelemetry so that I can able to push logs into the OT?

 Please suggest any solution around the same.

Below is the url which I have referred for above serilog-sink-opentelemetry implementation using OpenTelemetry extension method
https://github.com/open-telemetry/opentelemetry-dotnet.git

Refere Proj: OpenTelemetry-DotnNet - example -> LoggingExtensions -> Program.
                   OpenTelemetry.Extensions.Serilog


**Reproduction**
Code samples showing how you're configuring and calling Serilog to produce the behavior.

```
var openTelemetryLoggerProvider = Sdk.CreateLoggerProviderBuilder()
    .SetIncludeFormattedMessage(true)
    .ConfigureResource(builder => builder.AddService("Examples.LoggingExtensions"))
    .AddConsoleExporter()
    .Build();

// Configure Serilog global logger
Log.Logger = new LoggerConfiguration()
    .WriteTo.OpenTelemetry(
        openTelemetryLoggerProvider, // <- Register OpenTelemetry Serilog sink writing to openTelemetryLoggerProvider
        disposeProvider: false) 
.WriteTo.AmazonCloudWatch(cloudWatchConfig)
                    .WriteTo.Console()                    
                    .CreateLogger();
```

**Expected behavior**
Expected behaviour is, serilog will post logs into OpenTelemetry and using our existing flow, those logs would be added into LocalStack awscloudwatch.

**Relevant package, tooling and runtime versions**
Serilog.OpenTelemetry" Version="2.1.0"

**Additional context**
Please suggest any solution here.

Thanks...
Happy Coding....

issue.title: Errors exporting alerts during `template export`

comment.body:
That's great - thanks Daniel!

The `notificationAppInstanceId` thing is a "working as intended" feature - if imported alerts are going to send notifications then they need to be configured with the id of an app instance to use, which is specified on the `seqcli template import` command-line, e.g. as `-g notificationAppInstanceId=appinstance-19'`.

Does this make sense in your case, though? You might be in the best position to make a call on the usefulness of this behavior... I wonder if, for alerts, we should instead just drop off their notification channels, and rely on these being reconfigured by hand after-the-fact? Or is there some other scheme that would make alert import/export work better?

I don't think exporting the apps/app instances would turn out well, because they generally rely on very specific details (endpoint URIs, passwords, etc.) that won't make sense to transfer between systems using templates.

Perhaps another option might be for the `import` command to find existing app instances somehow and match them up - but there's a lot of room for bad behavior if it gets things wrong 🤔

comment.body:
Hi Juliano! Thanks for the note.

It's all really going to come down to someone actually needing/wanting an OTEL sink enough to do the research and build one, right now. In the past, every relevant log destination (hundreds of them) has ended up with Serilog support that way. OTEL isn't any different - if someone wants it I think they'll build it whether there's an open issue or not :-)

The challenge is that like all standards, OTEL for logging is something of a lowest-common-denominator. For example, given that a Serilog sink already exists for Elasticsearch that understands all the intricacies of Elasticsearch clusters, indexes, etc., it's not likely anyone would choose a generic sink instead. The situation with other services is similar - I think this might only really change when new/exclusively OTEL logging destinations start to appear.

Are you planning to use a server/service for which OTEL would be the best transport, or where no useful Serilog sink currently exists? Or even just super interested in exploring OTEL? If so, that would be a golden opportunity to help shape something up. If you can stand up a GitHub repo and start hacking away on it, I'd be keen to help you identify useful prior art and unblock any issues that you hit. Let me know if so!

The best way to try moving this forward without burning too much time on it might be to hack together a proof-of-concept approach, and write up what you find in a new issue in `serilog/serilog` - we can then run through it and try to make a call on whether more effort is likely to yield success. Let me know what you think.

issue.title: SeriLog.Sinks.File/SeriLog.Sinks.Async Fails To Log All Data

comment.body:
Hi @Mohammad-Moussa-Haidar -

There's always going to be a problem if the log source produces events faster than the sink can emit them. When you're logging in a tight loop, that's always going to be the case - it's much faster to allocate events in memory than it is to write them out to disk.

When this happens there are three possible outcomes -

 * You fill up RAM and eventually OOM
 * You drop events
 * You wait for the sink to catch up

Serilog steers you towards the latter two and gives you the choice which you prefer.

(You might have another option which meets your requirements - obtain a much faster disk 🤔)

In normal applications though:

 * The app actually does something, so rarely if ever will generate logs fast enough to saturate disk
 * The most important performance number is the added latency on the application/logging side, which Serilog.Sinks.Async deals with quite well (on the sink side, only throughput really matters in this case)

Not sure if there's much more I can add but hopefully you find a solution to fit your requirements - all the best with it!

issue.title: SeriLog.Sinks.File/SeriLog.Sinks.Async Fails To Log All Data

comment.body:
Thanks for dropping by!

The performance comparison is meaningless unless the custom file logger has equivalent features to Serilog: message template capturing, a concurrent structured logging pipeline with enrichment, etc. etc..

There's definitely still room to beat Serilog's performance using newer .NET features, but there's not much point comparing performance unless you're matching features. Bottleneck finding is always welcome though, so if you do figure out any specific ways Serilog could improve by all means please do let us know :-)

Just in case it helps you to reach your perf goals - you're using the Serilog file logger in blocking mode, you should [let it buffer](https://github.com/serilog/serilog-sinks-file/blob/dev/src/Serilog.Sinks.File/FileLoggerConfigurationExtensions.cs#L108) if you're comparing to a buffered implementation. You'll also then need to `CloseAndFlush()` before taking your perf measurements after making that change.

You might need to whittle your test code down to a minimal repro to figure out why you're not seeing all logs despite increasing the buffer size. It's possible there's some problem in the way the async sink works, but there's a lot of code still in your test harness, so it's quite likely once you start simplifying you'll find the problem there. Interested to hear what you find, either way!

Hope this helps,
Nick

issue.title: Time span string parsing handled inconsistently by `TotalMilliseconds()`
issue.body:
On my local machine (Seq 2022.1 on Windows 11) I can use `TotalMilliseconds` to convert a `TimeSpan` to milliseconds:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1189399/196863989-d05e3330-5503-42b3-a1f7-bb3e56e2095a.png)

Running the same query against our Seq server in production (2022.1, deployed in our Kubernetes cluster using Seq's helm chart) `TotalMilliseconds` cannot convert them:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1189399/196864209-b65496e4-bb0c-478a-bcf2-c5db23e4e3f2.png)

I hope this can be resolved easily! Thank you in advance.

comment.body: I think your summary matches the conclusions we reached 👍

issue.title: Seq instances managed by Helm can't parse TimeSpans
issue.body:
On my local machine (Seq 2022.1 on Windows 11) I can use `TotalMilliseconds` to convert a `TimeSpan` to milliseconds:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1189399/196863989-d05e3330-5503-42b3-a1f7-bb3e56e2095a.png)

Running the same query against our Seq server in production (2022.1, deployed in our Kubernetes cluster using Seq's helm chart) `TotalMilliseconds` cannot convert them:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1189399/196864209-b65496e4-bb0c-478a-bcf2-c5db23e4e3f2.png)

I hope this can be resolved easily! Thank you in advance.

comment.body:
Hi Todd, thanks for reaching out.

This is a bug - 2022.1 uses two different `TotalMilliseconds` functions (one when reading from cache, and one for results served from disk) and these have slightly different behavior. We've addressed this in 2023.1, where we're back to a single implementation only - I'll leave this issue open to check and confirm what the final decision on behavior was.

The `TotalMilliseconds()` function should generally only be used to work with numeric durations, e.g.:

```sql
select TotalMilliseconds(1h)
```

While the `TimeSpan` function is used for parsing strings in H:M:S format:

```sql
select TimeSpan('10:23:45')
```

The solution in the case you have here is to use:

```
TotalMilliseconds(TimeSpan(Duration))
```

and avoid the convenience conversion from duration strings that one of the `TotalMilliseconds` functions provides.

Hope this helps, please let me know if I've missed any important info.

issue.title: Add queue monitoring
issue.body:
This PR implements issue #61 .

I changed my mind on the way to monitor the queue...

Instead of configuring just a threshold that would trigger one callback when going above and another one when going below as proposed in the issue, i figured it is more interesting to monitor it "real time" with a timer and a callback that takes the number of events in the queue.

The hard part was to have a not flaky unit test (combination of the new monitoring timer with the existing timer was quite hard to synchronize in tests). After a lot of effort to try to make it work, i decided to create a way to mock the timers and have a better control over the timing.

The impact of this refactoring seems reasonable to me as there is no change publicly, just a new internal constructor only visible in tests (so the PortableTimer is still not visible by users of the lib).

Let me know if you agree with the approach !

issue.title: Ingesting logs from `journalctl` as json, and parsing timestamps
issue.body:
I was pointed at `seqcli` which apparently could be used in a tailing fashion with journalctl to read journald logs. I tried it out, and instead of reading and parsing text, I went the route with json parsing (to get all the structured logs goodies).

I came up with this:
```
journalctl -f -o json | \
  jq -c '. + {
    "@m":.MESSAGE,
    "host":._HOSTNAME,
    "@l":(.PRIORITY|tonumber),
    "@t":(.__REALTIME_TIMESTAMP|tonumber)} | 
    del(.MESSAGE, ._HOSTNAME,.PRIORITY,.__REALTIME_TIMESTAMP)
  ' | seqcli ingest --json
```

There are a few points here:
* The timestamp is rejected by `seqcli ingest`, with `The value of `@t` on line 1 is not in a supported format.`
  * I could format the timestamp (unix milliseconds) as some datetime, but I think that's a waste..
* Should I lowercase all properties?
* I couldn't pass in json unless it was newline delimited, I kinda expected that to work though - compact is better anyways, but maybe some source doesn't come in compact in the future ..
* I'll submit this as an alternate to your command in the docs when it's pretty :)

comment.body:
Given that the current `ingest` functionality isn't designed with the kind of sophistication in mind that this sort of feature requires, we might be better off closing this one. I'd dearly love to start building some basic ingest pipeline functionality here though, of course :-)

Just on the CLEF format and lack of PR-able docs, I put this repo and spec together - https://github.com/clef-json/clef-json.github.io - the format is published at https://clef-json.org/.

issue.title: Enables updating the configured min-level overrides at runtime
issue.body:
In response to https://github.com/serilog/serilog-settings-configuration/issues/284#issuecomment-1289664499, this PR shows my attempt to add the ability to replace the set of minimum log level overrides at runtime. The goal is to make it possible to refresh when appsettings.json changes on disk.

My approach attempts to avoid compromising performance or multicore contention at:
https://github.com/serilog/serilog/blob/4d13be50c03e14b6072043799dc7e5dbe4139a19/src/Serilog/Core/LevelOverrideMap.cs#L35-L41
by atomically updating the `LevelOverrideMap` reference with a new snapshot, instead of switching to a concurrent collection.

comment.body:
Thanks for taking a look! Unfortunately, the `IDisposable` implementation on `Logger` is only exposed on the root logging pipeline; child loggers like those produced by `ForContext` are exposed only as the non-disposable `ILogger`, and the API doesn't require or allow disposing these, so the changes would leak all child loggers via their event subscriptions.

The event handling subscribe/unsubscribe/synchronization costs are also a significant factor since in Serilog's design, contextual loggers are cheap/throwaway - it's common to see them created at pretty high frequency.

Digging through this again is reminding me why my conclusions last time were that it's a feature that's somewhat at odds with the way Serilog is designed. Still happy digging in, here, but thinking chances of finding a successful approach might be modest :-)

Just thinking back to your original ticket for a second - have you investigated the reconfigurable "reloadable logger" approach that we currently bundle up with Serilog.Extensions.Hosting?:

https://github.com/serilog/serilog-extensions-hosting/blob/dev/src/Serilog.Extensions.Hosting/Extensions/Hosting/ReloadableLogger.cs

It's fully reconfigurable; it's designed to be eventually "frozen" into a permanent, non-reconfigurable form, but you may have some luck incorporating it/tweaking it to reduce the costs of keeping it in a permanently mutable state 🤔 ... let me know if this might be a lower-effort way to get the behavior you're after.

issue.title: Plan of attack/call-to-action
issue.body:
I've dug into the official OpenTelemetry libraries for .NET - there's a lot of machinery there, and it seems questionable to want to run it all side-by-side with Serilog (better to use one or the other).

From that point of view, given the ultimate simplicity of the OTel logs protocol, I think the sink will be more useful by taking a lightweight approach and implementing the protocol directly with HTTP or gRPC and protocol buffers.

Here's my current plan - anyone interested in lending a hand, please let me know :-)

 - [ ] generate gRPC client types based on the protocol spec; see e.g. `OpenTelemetry.Exporter.OpenTelemetryProtocol.csproj` in the `opentelemetry-dotnet` repo
 - [ ] implement a mapping from batched `LogEvent`s to `ExportLogsServiceRequest`s
 - [ ] figure out what the sink's `Options` type will look like - e.g. accept the collector's HTTP base URL, etc.
 - [ ] implement _Serilog.Sinks.PeriodicBatching_'s `IBatchedLogEventSink` to construct requests, blast them through an `HttpClient`
 - [ ] wire everything up through logger sink configuration extensions
 - [ ] make some calls on how ambient trace and span ids will be determined by the sink (i.e. either through enriched log events, or by collecting them directly)

... or something close to that!

issue.title: Remove Sinks at runtime via XML
issue.body:
**Does this issue relate to a new *feature* or an existing *bug*?**
- [ ] Bug
- [x] New Feature
- [x] Question


Is it possible to remove a Sink via XML/configuration? 

It is possible to add a Sink via XML:

```XML
    <add key="serilog:using:RollingFile" value="Serilog.Sinks.RollingFile" />
    <add key="serilog:write-to:RollingFile.pathFormat" value="D:\log-{Date}.txt" />
```

But now I have the following situation: In a helper class I have a method (so in code) that creates a "default Serilog LoggerConfiguration". Multiple apps/libs can use this so the configuration is managed in a central place. 
But now I want to remove a sink for a specific app, at runtime.

Is it possible / It would be nice to remove a sink via XML, like:
```XML
    <add key="serilog:remove:using:RollingFile" value="Serilog.Sinks.RollingFile" />
```

This way I can "override" my default LoggerConfiguration that I have defined in code.

comment.body: Serilog 2.12's `CreateBootstrapLogger()` now provides this; please check out https://nblumhardt.com/2020/10/bootstrap-logger/ for one example of usage. If you need help figuring out how to integrate it into your app, the `serilog` tag on Stack Overflow is the most active channel. Thanks!

issue.title: Update OpenSSL to exclude the possibility of any impact from CVE-2022-3602 and CVE-2022-3786
issue.body:
[CVE-2022-3602 and CVE-2022-3786](https://www.openssl.org/news/secadv/20221101.txt) affect the OpenSSL library, which appears in various contexts platform library or embedded dependency. These issues are currently understood to be denial-of-service vectors causing application crashes on mainstream platforms.

We're currently investigating potential impacts on Seq. At this point we expect impact to be low, however we expect to publish patched releases for all target platforms regardless.

issue.title: Enables updating the configured min-level overrides at runtime
issue.body:
In response to https://github.com/serilog/serilog-settings-configuration/issues/284#issuecomment-1289664499, this PR shows my attempt to add the ability to replace the set of minimum log level overrides at runtime. The goal is to make it possible to refresh when appsettings.json changes on disk.

My approach attempts to avoid compromising performance or multicore contention at:
https://github.com/serilog/serilog/blob/4d13be50c03e14b6072043799dc7e5dbe4139a19/src/Serilog/Core/LevelOverrideMap.cs#L35-L41
by atomically updating the `LevelOverrideMap` reference with a new snapshot, instead of switching to a concurrent collection.

comment.body: Thanks @bart-vmware. If you create all of your loggers outside of the loop (i.e. don't make fresh `ForContext()` calls after reconfiguring the override map) then I tdon't think the existing loggers will update to reflect the new levels. (This is the kind of predictability issue that might be hard to solve without regressing performance, IIRC.)

issue.title: Update OpenSSL to exclude the possibility of any impact from CVE-2022-3602 and CVE-2022-3786
issue.body:
[CVE-2022-3602 and CVE-2022-3786](https://www.openssl.org/news/secadv/20221101.txt) affect the OpenSSL library, which appears in various contexts platform library or embedded dependency. These issues are currently understood to be denial-of-service vectors causing application crashes on mainstream platforms.

We're currently investigating potential impacts on Seq. At this point we expect impact to be low, however we expect to publish patched releases for all target platforms regardless.

issue.title: No exceptions emitted when generated by faulty audit log configuration
issue.body:
Combining this with an audit log Serilog configuration, exceptions are swallowed and never emitted back to the caller as would be expected.

Steps to reproduce:

1. Set up an audit logging configuration for Serilog which is purposefully mal-configured (for example, using the MS SQL Server sink to log events to a non-existent database table).
2. Implement logging using Microsoft.Extensions.Logging.Abstractions and an ILogger<T> using this library.
3. Emit a log event (`logger.LogInformation("test");`)

Expected behaviour: Exception to be thrown at the call to `LogInformation()`.

Actual behaviour:

- No exception is thrown
- The underlying exception is visible in Serilog's SelfLog

It looks like the culprit of this behaviour is here:

https://github.com/serilog/serilog-extensions-logging/blob/7141ae23125cbdb6b67df6f9aab1c42f1fa58366/src/Serilog.Extensions.Logging/Extensions/Logging/SerilogLogger.cs#L67-L74

Apologies for posting this up as an issue with no accompanying pull request but that's somewhat down to time constraints right now and largely because I'm not sure what the implications of changing this are likely to be. The obvious fix for this specific problem as I see it would just be to get rid of the try/catch block entirely and assume that if an exception is encountered, it's something we care about. However I am aware that my scenario is probably quite specific (it seems like audit logging is far less common than regular logging where errors _should_ be ignored) and my proposed 'fix' might well create new problems for people in other scenarios. And/or not account for other possible causes of exceptions which don't relate to the underlying Serilog logger having emitted them.

Let me know if I can add anything more to clarify and/or if I'm barking up the wrong tree here with this.

comment.body:
Thanks for the follow-up, Mark.

On the paths where you need auditing, perhaps using Serilog's `ILogger`/`Log` class directly is the way to go? Cheers!

issue.title: :l format not respected for items in StructureValue

comment.body: I was thinking along the lines of converting the whole structure to a JSON string, and then using `:l` to format it out through the template. It's not a particularly straightforward thing to implement currently, unfortunately.

issue.title: Error when grouping by nullable properties for Alerts
issue.body:
Hi when grouping by a property that is null or sometimes null the Alerts page just says

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3257270/198025229-ca3fc5fc-c6d0-41d7-848d-92627827ff39.png)

This is how the alert is defined
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3257270/198021836-492ecedc-7245-439e-b753-2730516acfdb.png)

Tested on 2021.3 and 2022.1 and its the same on both

comment.body:
Thanks for reporting this @pegasy - definitely a bug here 👍 

As a workaround, you can use something like `coalesce(property_that_does_not_exist, '<null>')` to use a placeholder string value for those missing groups.

We'll get this fixed, thanks again.

issue.title: Annotate Serilog for trimming
issue.body:
Most of serilog is trim-compatible. The main incompatibility is
configuration settings which scan assemblies at run time.
Serilog.Settings.Configuration is the more difficult challenge.

comment.body:
Great! It looks like there are still some problems to resolve -

```

issue.title: Serilog.Sinks.OpenTelemetry
issue.body:
**Description**
The main thing I want to implement is, I have to post logs into LocalStack awsclouwatch.
As we have post logs into the LocalStack awscloudwatch service using serilog the same need to implement using opentelemetry.

Since I can't find much on above statement, I thought to use serilog extension to post logs into the OpenTelemtry and use the existing flow of using serilog to see those OpenTelemetry logs in LocalStack awscloudewatch. 

For that I Used **Serilog.OpenTelemetry" Version="2.1.0"** nuget package but I am facing issues with
-  an extention method OpenTelemetry. 
-  Sdk.CreateLoggerProviderBuilder()
- not getting a reference of a class OpenTelemetrySerilogSink 
Since, above issues are with this nuget, just would like to ask,

Do Serilog provide any extension functionality compatible with OpenTelemetry so that I can able to push logs into the OT?

 Please suggest any solution around the same.

Below is the url which I have referred for above serilog-sink-opentelemetry implementation using OpenTelemetry extension method
https://github.com/open-telemetry/opentelemetry-dotnet.git

Refere Proj: OpenTelemetry-DotnNet - example -> LoggingExtensions -> Program.
                   OpenTelemetry.Extensions.Serilog


**Reproduction**
Code samples showing how you're configuring and calling Serilog to produce the behavior.

```
var openTelemetryLoggerProvider = Sdk.CreateLoggerProviderBuilder()
    .SetIncludeFormattedMessage(true)
    .ConfigureResource(builder => builder.AddService("Examples.LoggingExtensions"))
    .AddConsoleExporter()
    .Build();

// Configure Serilog global logger
Log.Logger = new LoggerConfiguration()
    .WriteTo.OpenTelemetry(
        openTelemetryLoggerProvider, // <- Register OpenTelemetry Serilog sink writing to openTelemetryLoggerProvider
        disposeProvider: false) 
.WriteTo.AmazonCloudWatch(cloudWatchConfig)
                    .WriteTo.Console()                    
                    .CreateLogger();
```

**Expected behavior**
Expected behaviour is, serilog will post logs into OpenTelemetry and using our existing flow, those logs would be added into LocalStack awscloudwatch.

**Relevant package, tooling and runtime versions**
Serilog.OpenTelemetry" Version="2.1.0"

**Additional context**
Please suggest any solution here.

Thanks...
Happy Coding....

issue.title: Errors exporting alerts during `template export`

comment.body:
That's great - thanks Daniel!

The `notificationAppInstanceId` thing is a "working as intended" feature - if imported alerts are going to send notifications then they need to be configured with the id of an app instance to use, which is specified on the `seqcli template import` command-line, e.g. as `-g notificationAppInstanceId=appinstance-19'`.

Does this make sense in your case, though? You might be in the best position to make a call on the usefulness of this behavior... I wonder if, for alerts, we should instead just drop off their notification channels, and rely on these being reconfigured by hand after-the-fact? Or is there some other scheme that would make alert import/export work better?

I don't think exporting the apps/app instances would turn out well, because they generally rely on very specific details (endpoint URIs, passwords, etc.) that won't make sense to transfer between systems using templates.

Perhaps another option might be for the `import` command to find existing app instances somehow and match them up - but there's a lot of room for bad behavior if it gets things wrong 🤔

comment.body:
Hi Juliano! Thanks for the note.

It's all really going to come down to someone actually needing/wanting an OTEL sink enough to do the research and build one, right now. In the past, every relevant log destination (hundreds of them) has ended up with Serilog support that way. OTEL isn't any different - if someone wants it I think they'll build it whether there's an open issue or not :-)

The challenge is that like all standards, OTEL for logging is something of a lowest-common-denominator. For example, given that a Serilog sink already exists for Elasticsearch that understands all the intricacies of Elasticsearch clusters, indexes, etc., it's not likely anyone would choose a generic sink instead. The situation with other services is similar - I think this might only really change when new/exclusively OTEL logging destinations start to appear.

Are you planning to use a server/service for which OTEL would be the best transport, or where no useful Serilog sink currently exists? Or even just super interested in exploring OTEL? If so, that would be a golden opportunity to help shape something up. If you can stand up a GitHub repo and start hacking away on it, I'd be keen to help you identify useful prior art and unblock any issues that you hit. Let me know if so!

issue.title: SeriLog.Sinks.File/SeriLog.Sinks.Async Fails To Log All Data

comment.body:
Hi @Mohammad-Moussa-Haidar -

There's always going to be a problem if the log source produces events faster than the sink can emit them. When you're logging in a tight loop, that's always going to be the case - it's much faster to allocate events in memory than it is to write them out to disk.

When this happens there are three possible outcomes -

 * You fill up RAM and eventually OOM
 * You drop events
 * You wait for the sink to catch up

Serilog steers you towards the latter two and gives you the choice which you prefer.

(You might have another option which meets your requirements - obtain a much faster disk 🤔)

In normal applications though:

 * The app actually does something, so rarely if ever will generate logs fast enough to saturate disk
 * The most important performance number is the added latency on the application/logging side, which Serilog.Sinks.Async deals with quite well (on the sink side, only throughput really matters in this case)

Not sure if there's much more I can add but hopefully you find a solution to fit your requirements - all the best with it!

issue.title: Support multiple commands on the seq-cli docker image
issue.body:
I have a docker compose which sets up the seq web image and then sets up the api key but I can only run one command. I would also like to be able to setup some default signals. Currently I do this:

```
services:
  seq-cli:
    container_name: seq-cli
    image: datalust/seqcli:latest
    command: apikey create --title='default' --token='12345678901234567890' --server=http://seq-web
    depends_on:
      - seq-web
    restart: on-failure
    networks:
      - local-infrastructure

  seq-web:
    container_name: seq-web
    image: datalust/seq:latest
    environment:
      ACCEPT_EULA: 'Y'
    restart: unless-stopped
    networks:
      - local-infrastructure
    ports:
      - '5341:5341'
      - '5342:80'
```

Without duplicating a bunch of things I cannot run multiple commands. It would be nice to be able to do this:

```
  seq-cli:
    container_name: seq-cli
    image: datalust/seqcli:latest
    command:
      - apikey create --title='default' --token='12345678901234567890' --server=http://seq-web
      - signal create ...
```

issue.title: SeriLog.Sinks.File/SeriLog.Sinks.Async Fails To Log All Data

comment.body:
Thanks for dropping by!

The performance comparison is meaningless unless the custom file logger has equivalent features to Serilog: message template capturing, a concurrent structured logging pipeline with enrichment, etc. etc..

There's definitely still room to beat Serilog's performance using newer .NET features, but there's not much point comparing performance unless you're matching features. Bottleneck finding is always welcome though, so if you do figure out any specific ways Serilog could improve by all means please do let us know :-)

Just in case it helps you to reach your perf goals - you're using the Serilog file logger in blocking mode, you should [let it buffer](https://github.com/serilog/serilog-sinks-file/blob/dev/src/Serilog.Sinks.File/FileLoggerConfigurationExtensions.cs#L108) if you're comparing to a buffered implementation. You'll also then need to `CloseAndFlush()` before taking your perf measurements after making that change.

You might need to whittle your test code down to a minimal repro to figure out why you're not seeing all logs despite increasing the buffer size. It's possible there's some problem in the way the async sink works, but there's a lot of code still in your test harness, so it's quite likely once you start simplifying you'll find the problem there. Interested to hear what you find, either way!

Hope this helps,
Nick

issue.title: Time span string parsing handled inconsistently by `TotalMilliseconds()`
issue.body:
On my local machine (Seq 2022.1 on Windows 11) I can use `TotalMilliseconds` to convert a `TimeSpan` to milliseconds:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1189399/196863989-d05e3330-5503-42b3-a1f7-bb3e56e2095a.png)

Running the same query against our Seq server in production (2022.1, deployed in our Kubernetes cluster using Seq's helm chart) `TotalMilliseconds` cannot convert them:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1189399/196864209-b65496e4-bb0c-478a-bcf2-c5db23e4e3f2.png)

I hope this can be resolved easily! Thank you in advance.

issue.title: Seq instances managed by Helm can't parse TimeSpans
issue.body:
On my local machine (Seq 2022.1 on Windows 11) I can use `TotalMilliseconds` to convert a `TimeSpan` to milliseconds:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1189399/196863989-d05e3330-5503-42b3-a1f7-bb3e56e2095a.png)

Running the same query against our Seq server in production (2022.1, deployed in our Kubernetes cluster using Seq's helm chart) `TotalMilliseconds` cannot convert them:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1189399/196864209-b65496e4-bb0c-478a-bcf2-c5db23e4e3f2.png)

I hope this can be resolved easily! Thank you in advance.

comment.body:
Hi Todd, thanks for reaching out.

This is a bug - 2022.1 uses two different `TotalMilliseconds` functions (one when reading from cache, and one for results served from disk) and these have slightly different behavior. We've addressed this in 2023.1, where we're back to a single implementation only - I'll leave this issue open to check and confirm what the final decision on behavior was.

The `TotalMilliseconds()` function should generally only be used to work with numeric durations, e.g.:

```sql
select TotalMilliseconds(1h)
```

While the `TimeSpan` function is used for parsing strings in H:M:S format:

```sql
select TimeSpan('10:23:45')
```

The solution in the case you have here is to use:

```
TotalMilliseconds(TimeSpan(Duration))
```

and avoid the convenience conversion from duration strings that one of the `TotalMilliseconds` functions provides.

Hope this helps, please let me know if I've missed any important info.

issue.title: Add queue monitoring
issue.body:
This PR implements issue #61 .

I changed my mind on the way to monitor the queue...

Instead of configuring just a threshold that would trigger one callback when going above and another one when going below as proposed in the issue, i figured it is more interesting to monitor it "real time" with a timer and a callback that takes the number of events in the queue.

The hard part was to have a not flaky unit test (combination of the new monitoring timer with the existing timer was quite hard to synchronize in tests). After a lot of effort to try to make it work, i decided to create a way to mock the timers and have a better control over the timing.

The impact of this refactoring seems reasonable to me as there is no change publicly, just a new internal constructor only visible in tests (so the PortableTimer is still not visible by users of the lib).

Let me know if you agree with the approach !

issue.title: Ingesting logs from `journalctl` as json, and parsing timestamps
issue.body:
I was pointed at `seqcli` which apparently could be used in a tailing fashion with journalctl to read journald logs. I tried it out, and instead of reading and parsing text, I went the route with json parsing (to get all the structured logs goodies).

I came up with this:
```
journalctl -f -o json | \
  jq -c '. + {
    "@m":.MESSAGE,
    "host":._HOSTNAME,
    "@l":(.PRIORITY|tonumber),
    "@t":(.__REALTIME_TIMESTAMP|tonumber)} | 
    del(.MESSAGE, ._HOSTNAME,.PRIORITY,.__REALTIME_TIMESTAMP)
  ' | seqcli ingest --json
```

There are a few points here:
* The timestamp is rejected by `seqcli ingest`, with `The value of `@t` on line 1 is not in a supported format.`
  * I could format the timestamp (unix milliseconds) as some datetime, but I think that's a waste..
* Should I lowercase all properties?
* I couldn't pass in json unless it was newline delimited, I kinda expected that to work though - compact is better anyways, but maybe some source doesn't come in compact in the future ..
* I'll submit this as an alternate to your command in the docs when it's pretty :)

comment.body:
Given that the current `ingest` functionality isn't designed with the kind of sophistication in mind that this sort of feature requires, we might be better off closing this one. I'd dearly love to start building some basic ingest pipeline functionality here though, of course :-)

Just on the CLEF format and lack of PR-able docs, I put this repo and spec together - https://github.com/clef-json/clef-json.github.io - the format is published at https://clef-json.org/.

issue.title: Support multiple commands on the seq-cli docker image
issue.body:
I have a docker compose which sets up the seq web image and then sets up the api key but I can only run one command. I would also like to be able to setup some default signals. Currently I do this:

```
services:
  seq-cli:
    container_name: seq-cli
    image: datalust/seqcli:latest
    command: apikey create --title='default' --token='12345678901234567890' --server=http://seq-web
    depends_on:
      - seq-web
    restart: on-failure
    networks:
      - local-infrastructure

  seq-web:
    container_name: seq-web
    image: datalust/seq:latest
    environment:
      ACCEPT_EULA: 'Y'
    restart: unless-stopped
    networks:
      - local-infrastructure
    ports:
      - '5341:5341'
      - '5342:80'
```

Without duplicating a bunch of things I cannot run multiple commands. It would be nice to be able to do this:

```
  seq-cli:
    container_name: seq-cli
    image: datalust/seqcli:latest
    command:
      - apikey create --title='default' --token='12345678901234567890' --server=http://seq-web
      - signal create ...
```

comment.body:
Hi @bronumski! Looking at this again, I think it's unlikely we'll pursue multiple commands directly on the command-line in the near future: we already have both `seqcli template *` and Seq init scripts to support this scenario in different ways, and both are more capable than anything we'd be able to do within the constraints of a single command-line.

Did init scripts work out for you? Are you happy for us to close this one? Thanks!

issue.title: Enables updating the configured min-level overrides at runtime
issue.body:
In response to https://github.com/serilog/serilog-settings-configuration/issues/284#issuecomment-1289664499, this PR shows my attempt to add the ability to replace the set of minimum log level overrides at runtime. The goal is to make it possible to refresh when appsettings.json changes on disk.

My approach attempts to avoid compromising performance or multicore contention at:
https://github.com/serilog/serilog/blob/4d13be50c03e14b6072043799dc7e5dbe4139a19/src/Serilog/Core/LevelOverrideMap.cs#L35-L41
by atomically updating the `LevelOverrideMap` reference with a new snapshot, instead of switching to a concurrent collection.

comment.body:
Thanks for taking a look! Unfortunately, the `IDisposable` implementation on `Logger` is only exposed on the root logging pipeline; child loggers like those produced by `ForContext` are exposed only as the non-disposable `ILogger`, and the API doesn't require or allow disposing these, so the changes would leak all child loggers via their event subscriptions.

The event handling subscribe/unsubscribe/synchronization costs are also a significant factor since in Serilog's design, contextual loggers are cheap/throwaway - it's common to see them created at pretty high frequency.

Digging through this again is reminding me why my conclusions last time were that it's a feature that's somewhat at odds with the way Serilog is designed. Still happy digging in, here, but thinking chances of finding a successful approach might be modest :-)

Just thinking back to your original ticket for a second - have you investigated the reconfigurable "reloadable logger" approach that we currently bundle up with Serilog.Extensions.Hosting?:

https://github.com/serilog/serilog-extensions-hosting/blob/dev/src/Serilog.Extensions.Hosting/Extensions/Hosting/ReloadableLogger.cs

It's fully reconfigurable; it's designed to be eventually "frozen" into a permanent, non-reconfigurable form, but you may have some luck incorporating it/tweaking it to reduce the costs of keeping it in a permanently mutable state 🤔 ... let me know if this might be a lower-effort way to get the behavior you're after.

issue.title: Plan of attack/call-to-action
issue.body:
I've dug into the official OpenTelemetry libraries for .NET - there's a lot of machinery there, and it seems questionable to want to run it all side-by-side with Serilog (better to use one or the other).

From that point of view, given the ultimate simplicity of the OTel logs protocol, I think the sink will be more useful by taking a lightweight approach and implementing the protocol directly with HTTP or gRPC and protocol buffers.

Here's my current plan - anyone interested in lending a hand, please let me know :-)

 - [ ] generate gRPC client types based on the protocol spec; see e.g. `OpenTelemetry.Exporter.OpenTelemetryProtocol.csproj` in the `opentelemetry-dotnet` repo
 - [ ] implement a mapping from batched `LogEvent`s to `ExportLogsServiceRequest`s
 - [ ] figure out what the sink's `Options` type will look like - e.g. accept the collector's HTTP base URL, etc.
 - [ ] implement _Serilog.Sinks.PeriodicBatching_'s `IBatchedLogEventSink` to construct requests, blast them through an `HttpClient`
 - [ ] wire everything up through logger sink configuration extensions
 - [ ] make some calls on how ambient trace and span ids will be determined by the sink (i.e. either through enriched log events, or by collecting them directly)

... or something close to that!

issue.title: Remove Sinks at runtime via XML
issue.body:
**Does this issue relate to a new *feature* or an existing *bug*?**
- [ ] Bug
- [x] New Feature
- [x] Question


Is it possible to remove a Sink via XML/configuration? 

It is possible to add a Sink via XML:

```XML
    <add key="serilog:using:RollingFile" value="Serilog.Sinks.RollingFile" />
    <add key="serilog:write-to:RollingFile.pathFormat" value="D:\log-{Date}.txt" />
```

But now I have the following situation: In a helper class I have a method (so in code) that creates a "default Serilog LoggerConfiguration". Multiple apps/libs can use this so the configuration is managed in a central place. 
But now I want to remove a sink for a specific app, at runtime.

Is it possible / It would be nice to remove a sink via XML, like:
```XML
    <add key="serilog:remove:using:RollingFile" value="Serilog.Sinks.RollingFile" />
```

This way I can "override" my default LoggerConfiguration that I have defined in code.

comment.body: Serilog 2.12's `CreateBootstrapLogger()` now provides this; please check out https://nblumhardt.com/2020/10/bootstrap-logger/ for one example of usage. If you need help figuring out how to integrate it into your app, the `serilog` tag on Stack Overflow is the most active channel. Thanks!

issue.title: Update OpenSSL to exclude the possibility of any impact from CVE-2022-3602 and CVE-2022-3786
issue.body:
[CVE-2022-3602 and CVE-2022-3786](https://www.openssl.org/news/secadv/20221101.txt) affect the OpenSSL library, which appears in various contexts platform library or embedded dependency. These issues are currently understood to be denial-of-service vectors causing application crashes on mainstream platforms.

We're currently investigating potential impacts on Seq. At this point we expect impact to be low, however we expect to publish patched releases for all target platforms regardless.

issue.title: No exceptions emitted when generated by faulty audit log configuration
issue.body:
Combining this with an audit log Serilog configuration, exceptions are swallowed and never emitted back to the caller as would be expected.

Steps to reproduce:

1. Set up an audit logging configuration for Serilog which is purposefully mal-configured (for example, using the MS SQL Server sink to log events to a non-existent database table).
2. Implement logging using Microsoft.Extensions.Logging.Abstractions and an ILogger<T> using this library.
3. Emit a log event (`logger.LogInformation("test");`)

Expected behaviour: Exception to be thrown at the call to `LogInformation()`.

Actual behaviour:

- No exception is thrown
- The underlying exception is visible in Serilog's SelfLog

It looks like the culprit of this behaviour is here:

https://github.com/serilog/serilog-extensions-logging/blob/7141ae23125cbdb6b67df6f9aab1c42f1fa58366/src/Serilog.Extensions.Logging/Extensions/Logging/SerilogLogger.cs#L67-L74

Apologies for posting this up as an issue with no accompanying pull request but that's somewhat down to time constraints right now and largely because I'm not sure what the implications of changing this are likely to be. The obvious fix for this specific problem as I see it would just be to get rid of the try/catch block entirely and assume that if an exception is encountered, it's something we care about. However I am aware that my scenario is probably quite specific (it seems like audit logging is far less common than regular logging where errors _should_ be ignored) and my proposed 'fix' might well create new problems for people in other scenarios. And/or not account for other possible causes of exceptions which don't relate to the underlying Serilog logger having emitted them.

Let me know if I can add anything more to clarify and/or if I'm barking up the wrong tree here with this.

comment.body:
Thanks for the follow-up, Mark.

On the paths where you need auditing, perhaps using Serilog's `ILogger`/`Log` class directly is the way to go? Cheers!

issue.title: No exceptions emitted when generated by faulty audit log configuration
issue.body:
Combining this with an audit log Serilog configuration, exceptions are swallowed and never emitted back to the caller as would be expected.

Steps to reproduce:

1. Set up an audit logging configuration for Serilog which is purposefully mal-configured (for example, using the MS SQL Server sink to log events to a non-existent database table).
2. Implement logging using Microsoft.Extensions.Logging.Abstractions and an ILogger<T> using this library.
3. Emit a log event (`logger.LogInformation("test");`)

Expected behaviour: Exception to be thrown at the call to `LogInformation()`.

Actual behaviour:

- No exception is thrown
- The underlying exception is visible in Serilog's SelfLog

It looks like the culprit of this behaviour is here:

https://github.com/serilog/serilog-extensions-logging/blob/7141ae23125cbdb6b67df6f9aab1c42f1fa58366/src/Serilog.Extensions.Logging/Extensions/Logging/SerilogLogger.cs#L67-L74

Apologies for posting this up as an issue with no accompanying pull request but that's somewhat down to time constraints right now and largely because I'm not sure what the implications of changing this are likely to be. The obvious fix for this specific problem as I see it would just be to get rid of the try/catch block entirely and assume that if an exception is encountered, it's something we care about. However I am aware that my scenario is probably quite specific (it seems like audit logging is far less common than regular logging where errors _should_ be ignored) and my proposed 'fix' might well create new problems for people in other scenarios. And/or not account for other possible causes of exceptions which don't relate to the underlying Serilog logger having emitted them.

Let me know if I can add anything more to clarify and/or if I'm barking up the wrong tree here with this.

comment.body:
Thanks for the report, Mark!

Here's the original bug that led to the introduction of the try/catch block:

https://github.com/serilog/serilog-extensions-logging/issues/164

I'm not sure what the right approach is, needs some more consideration 🤔

issue.title: Serilog.Sinks.OpenTelemetry
issue.body:
**Description**
The main thing I want to implement is, I have to post logs into LocalStack awsclouwatch.
As we have post logs into the LocalStack awscloudwatch service using serilog the same need to implement using opentelemetry.

Since I can't find much on above statement, I thought to use serilog extension to post logs into the OpenTelemtry and use the existing flow of using serilog to see those OpenTelemetry logs in LocalStack awscloudewatch. 

For that I Used **Serilog.OpenTelemetry" Version="2.1.0"** nuget package but I am facing issues with
-  an extention method OpenTelemetry. 
-  Sdk.CreateLoggerProviderBuilder()
- not getting a reference of a class OpenTelemetrySerilogSink 
Since, above issues are with this nuget, just would like to ask,

Do Serilog provide any extension functionality compatible with OpenTelemetry so that I can able to push logs into the OT?

 Please suggest any solution around the same.

Below is the url which I have referred for above serilog-sink-opentelemetry implementation using OpenTelemetry extension method
https://github.com/open-telemetry/opentelemetry-dotnet.git

Refere Proj: OpenTelemetry-DotnNet - example -> LoggingExtensions -> Program.
                   OpenTelemetry.Extensions.Serilog


**Reproduction**
Code samples showing how you're configuring and calling Serilog to produce the behavior.

```
var openTelemetryLoggerProvider = Sdk.CreateLoggerProviderBuilder()
    .SetIncludeFormattedMessage(true)
    .ConfigureResource(builder => builder.AddService("Examples.LoggingExtensions"))
    .AddConsoleExporter()
    .Build();

// Configure Serilog global logger
Log.Logger = new LoggerConfiguration()
    .WriteTo.OpenTelemetry(
        openTelemetryLoggerProvider, // <- Register OpenTelemetry Serilog sink writing to openTelemetryLoggerProvider
        disposeProvider: false) 
.WriteTo.AmazonCloudWatch(cloudWatchConfig)
                    .WriteTo.Console()                    
                    .CreateLogger();
```

**Expected behavior**
Expected behaviour is, serilog will post logs into OpenTelemetry and using our existing flow, those logs would be added into LocalStack awscloudwatch.

**Relevant package, tooling and runtime versions**
Serilog.OpenTelemetry" Version="2.1.0"

**Additional context**
Please suggest any solution here.

Thanks...
Happy Coding....

comment.body: https://github.com/serilog/serilog-sinks-opentelemetry - we can chip away here as time allows; I should be able to get a basic package build going later this week :-)

issue.title: :l format not respected for items in StructureValue

comment.body: Hi @sungam3r! The `:l` switch only controls string formatting in the message template; what I understand you want here is to change the effective type of `b` from Boolean to string; that would be a job for an enricher (or a custom function plugged into Serilog.Expressions), which would inspect the `StructureValue`/`ScalarValue` properties involved and replace/transform them.

issue.title: Errors exporting alerts during `template export`

comment.body:
That's great - thanks Daniel!

The `notificationAppInstanceId` thing is a "working as intended" feature - if imported alerts are going to send notifications then they need to be configured with the id of an app instance to use, which is specified on the `seqcli template import` command-line, e.g. as `-g notificationAppInstanceId=appinstance-19'`.

Does this make sense in your case, though? You might be in the best position to make a call on the usefulness of this behavior... I wonder if, for alerts, we should instead just drop off their notification channels, and rely on these being reconfigured by hand after-the-fact? Or is there some other scheme that would make alert import/export work better?

I don't think exporting the apps/app instances would turn out well, because they generally rely on very specific details (endpoint URIs, passwords, etc.) that won't make sense to transfer between systems using templates.

Perhaps another option might be for the `import` command to find existing app instances somehow and match them up - but there's a lot of room for bad behavior if it gets things wrong 🤔

comment.body:
Hi Juliano! Thanks for the note.

It's all really going to come down to someone actually needing/wanting an OTEL sink enough to do the research and build one, right now. In the past, every relevant log destination (hundreds of them) has ended up with Serilog support that way. OTEL isn't any different - if someone wants it I think they'll build it whether there's an open issue or not :-)

The challenge is that like all standards, OTEL for logging is something of a lowest-common-denominator. For example, given that a Serilog sink already exists for Elasticsearch that understands all the intricacies of Elasticsearch clusters, indexes, etc., it's not likely anyone would choose a generic sink instead. The situation with other services is similar - I think this might only really change when new/exclusively OTEL logging destinations start to appear.

Are you planning to use a server/service for which OTEL would be the best transport, or where no useful Serilog sink currently exists? Or even just super interested in exploring OTEL? If so, that would be a golden opportunity to help shape something up. If you can stand up a GitHub repo and start hacking away on it, I'd be keen to help you identify useful prior art and unblock any issues that you hit. Let me know if so!

issue.title: SeriLog.Sinks.File/SeriLog.Sinks.Async Fails To Log All Data

comment.body:
Hi @Mohammad-Moussa-Haidar -

There's always going to be a problem if the log source produces events faster than the sink can emit them. When you're logging in a tight loop, that's always going to be the case - it's much faster to allocate events in memory than it is to write them out to disk.

When this happens there are three possible outcomes -

 * You fill up RAM and eventually OOM
 * You drop events
 * You wait for the sink to catch up

Serilog steers you towards the latter two and gives you the choice which you prefer.

(You might have another option which meets your requirements - obtain a much faster disk 🤔)

In normal applications though:

 * The app actually does something, so rarely if ever will generate logs fast enough to saturate disk
 * The most important performance number is the added latency on the application/logging side, which Serilog.Sinks.Async deals with quite well (on the sink side, only throughput really matters in this case)

Not sure if there's much more I can add but hopefully you find a solution to fit your requirements - all the best with it!

issue.title: Support multiple commands on the seq-cli docker image
issue.body:
I have a docker compose which sets up the seq web image and then sets up the api key but I can only run one command. I would also like to be able to setup some default signals. Currently I do this:

```
services:
  seq-cli:
    container_name: seq-cli
    image: datalust/seqcli:latest
    command: apikey create --title='default' --token='12345678901234567890' --server=http://seq-web
    depends_on:
      - seq-web
    restart: on-failure
    networks:
      - local-infrastructure

  seq-web:
    container_name: seq-web
    image: datalust/seq:latest
    environment:
      ACCEPT_EULA: 'Y'
    restart: unless-stopped
    networks:
      - local-infrastructure
    ports:
      - '5341:5341'

    image: datalust/seqcli:latest

      - apikey create --title='default' --token='12345678901234567890' --server=http://seq-web

```

issue.title: SeriLog.Sinks.File/SeriLog.Sinks.Async Fails To Log All Data

comment.body:
Thanks for dropping by!

The performance comparison is meaningless unless the custom file logger has equivalent features to Serilog: message template capturing, a concurrent structured logging pipeline with enrichment, etc. etc..

There's definitely still room to beat Serilog's performance using newer .NET features, but there's not much point comparing performance unless you're matching features. Bottleneck finding is always welcome though, so if you do figure out any specific ways Serilog could improve by all means please do let us know :-)

Just in case it helps you to reach your perf goals - you're using the Serilog file logger in blocking mode, you should [let it buffer](https://github.com/serilog/serilog-sinks-file/blob/dev/src/Serilog.Sinks.File/FileLoggerConfigurationExtensions.cs#L108) if you're comparing to a buffered implementation. You'll also then need to `CloseAndFlush()` before taking your perf measurements after making that change.

You might need to whittle your test code down to a minimal repro to figure out why you're not seeing all logs despite increasing the buffer size. It's possible there's some problem in the way the async sink works, but there's a lot of code still in your test harness, so it's quite likely once you start simplifying you'll find the problem there. Interested to hear what you find, either way!

Hope this helps,
Nick

issue.body:
On my local machine (Seq 2022.1 on Windows 11) I can use `TotalMilliseconds` to convert a `TimeSpan` to milliseconds:

Running the same query against our Seq server in production (2022.1, deployed in our Kubernetes cluster using Seq's helm chart) `TotalMilliseconds` cannot convert them:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1189399/196864209-b65496e4-bb0c-478a-bcf2-c5db23e4e3f2.png)

issue.title: Seq instances managed by Helm can't parse TimeSpans
issue.body:
On my local machine (Seq 2022.1 on Windows 11) I can use `TotalMilliseconds` to convert a `TimeSpan` to milliseconds:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1189399/196863989-d05e3330-5503-42b3-a1f7-bb3e56e2095a.png)

Running the same query against our Seq server in production (2022.1, deployed in our Kubernetes cluster using Seq's helm chart) `TotalMilliseconds` cannot convert them:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1189399/196864209-b65496e4-bb0c-478a-bcf2-c5db23e4e3f2.png)

I hope this can be resolved easily! Thank you in advance.

comment.body:
Hi Todd, thanks for reaching out.

This is a bug - 2022.1 uses two different `TotalMilliseconds` functions (one when reading from cache, and one for results served from disk) and these have slightly different behavior. We've addressed this in 2023.1, where we're back to a single implementation only - I'll leave this issue open to check and confirm what the final decision on behavior was.

The `TotalMilliseconds()` function should generally only be used to work with numeric durations, e.g.:

```sql
select TotalMilliseconds(1h)
```

While the `TimeSpan` function is used for parsing strings in H:M:S format:

```sql
select TimeSpan('10:23:45')
```

The solution in the case you have here is to use:

```
TotalMilliseconds(TimeSpan(Duration))
```

and avoid the convenience conversion from duration strings that one of the `TotalMilliseconds` functions provides.

Hope this helps, please let me know if I've missed any important info.

issue.title: Add queue monitoring
issue.body:
This PR implements issue #61 .

I changed my mind on the way to monitor the queue...

Instead of configuring just a threshold that would trigger one callback when going above and another one when going below as proposed in the issue, i figured it is more interesting to monitor it "real time" with a timer and a callback that takes the number of events in the queue.

The hard part was to have a not flaky unit test (combination of the new monitoring timer with the existing timer was quite hard to synchronize in tests). After a lot of effort to try to make it work, i decided to create a way to mock the timers and have a better control over the timing.

The impact of this refactoring seems reasonable to me as there is no change publicly, just a new internal constructor only visible in tests (so the PortableTimer is still not visible by users of the lib).

Let me know if you agree with the approach !

issue.title: Ingesting logs from `journalctl` as json, and parsing timestamps
issue.body:
I was pointed at `seqcli` which apparently could be used in a tailing fashion with journalctl to read journald logs. I tried it out, and instead of reading and parsing text, I went the route with json parsing (to get all the structured logs goodies).

I came up with this:
```
journalctl -f -o json | \
  jq -c '. + {
    "@m":.MESSAGE,
    "host":._HOSTNAME,
    "@l":(.PRIORITY|tonumber),
    "@t":(.__REALTIME_TIMESTAMP|tonumber)} | 
    del(.MESSAGE, ._HOSTNAME,.PRIORITY,.__REALTIME_TIMESTAMP)
  ' | seqcli ingest --json
```

There are a few points here:
* The timestamp is rejected by `seqcli ingest`, with `The value of `@t` on line 1 is not in a supported format.`
  * I could format the timestamp (unix milliseconds) as some datetime, but I think that's a waste..
* Should I lowercase all properties?
* I couldn't pass in json unless it was newline delimited, I kinda expected that to work though - compact is better anyways, but maybe some source doesn't come in compact in the future ..
* I'll submit this as an alternate to your command in the docs when it's pretty :)

comment.body:
Given that the current `ingest` functionality isn't designed with the kind of sophistication in mind that this sort of feature requires, we might be better off closing this one. I'd dearly love to start building some basic ingest pipeline functionality here though, of course :-)

Just on the CLEF format and lack of PR-able docs, I put this repo and spec together - https://github.com/clef-json/clef-json.github.io - the format is published at https://clef-json.org/.
